list_definition.definition: having too much pride in one’s appearance, achievements etc; conceited

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: She’s very vain about her looks.
He made a vain attempt to reach the drowning woman.

list_ex_of_english: I too hoped and waited for one until now- but in vain.
List archives are a goldmine for the specialist tracing his or her memory in vain at the moment of need.
Still, one looks in vain for scholarship which takes union decline in this field to be a serious issue.
If there is truly nothing to be gained from being, then all schemes to ' improve ' the world are vain.
The reader will also look in vain for broad, explorative theoretical discussions of the possible determinants of societal value in health care.
In short, it was the moral type of the vain, the superficial and the narcissistic, and the only emotion it could inspire was 'contempt'.
He could hardly have expounded his position more clearly: quite bluntly, any plans to abolish music are described as vain.
Put another way, $97,000 would be spent in vain.
